caption: Table 1: Comparison of our work to existing literature-based biomedical datasets. BIOMEDICA stands out by offering 2x more scientific papers and 1.6x more image-caption pairs, metadata fields, support for streaming, and expert-curated concepts from clinicians and scientists. ∗See Table 2 for a full list of provided metadata.
description: This table compares BIOMEDICA to other literature-based biomedical datasets, highlighting BIOMEDICA's superior size (2x more scientific papers and 1.6x more image-caption pairs) and richer metadata (1.6x more fields).  It also notes BIOMEDICA's support for data streaming and its use of expert-curated concepts from clinicians and scientists.

caption: Table 2: List of image data (n=3), image metadata (n=5), image annotations (n=4), article metadata (n=13), and image embeddings (n=2) provided in \dataset dataset, alongside concept provenance.
description: This table lists all the data fields included in the BIOMEDICA dataset.  It's categorized into image data (raw image files, image keys, etc.), image metadata (image hash, panel type, etc.), image annotations (primary and secondary content labels, etc.), article metadata (PMCID, PMID, journal, license, etc.), and image embeddings (DINOv2 and PMC-CLIP features).  Each data field's origin (generated, from nXML, etc.) is also specified.  The table provides a comprehensive overview of the data available within BIOMEDICA, highlighting the richness and variety of information associated with each image-caption pair.

caption: Table 3: General Biomedical Imaging Classification Average zero-shot performance across 35 classification tasks (from 21 unique datasets) stratified by domain and task. We show results for three variants of our model, including continual pretraining on all of \dataset, a subset after concept-filtering (CF), and a subset after concept-balancing (CB). Models with indication WiSE-FT are merged counterparts as described in [59]. Bold indicates best performance, underline indicates second best performance.
description: This table presents the average zero-shot performance results for three variants of a vision-language model across 35 biomedical image classification tasks from 21 distinct datasets.  The model variants include one trained with continual pretraining on the full BIOMEDICA dataset, another trained on a concept-filtered subset, and a third trained on a concept-balanced subset.  The results are stratified by domain (biology, pathology, etc.) and task, allowing for detailed comparison across different model variations and task types.  Results using a merging technique (WiSE-FT) are also included for comparison.  The best-performing result for each task is shown in bold, while the second-best is underlined.

caption: Table 4: Top-K retrieval performance on BioMed-Flickr.Bold indicates best performance, underline indicates second best performance.
description: This table presents the Top-K retrieval performance results on the BioMed-Flickr dataset.  It compares various models, showing their Recall@1, Recall@10, and Recall@100 metrics.  Bold font highlights the best-performing model for each metric, while underlined font indicates the second-best performing model. This allows for a direct comparison of the models' abilities to retrieve relevant images from the dataset based on text queries.

caption: Table 5: Microscopy Composition Identification Performance in 4 course-grained classification tasks from μ𝜇\muitalic_μ-Bench Perception across pathology and biology. Bold indicates best performance, underline indicates second best performance.
description: This table presents the performance of different models on four course-grained microscopy composition identification tasks.  The tasks cover both pathology and biology, focusing on aspects such as the microscopy modality (e.g., light microscopy), staining technique, and the specific domain.  The table compares the performance of several models (OpenCLIP, CoCa, PMC-CLIP, BioMedCLIP, and different variants of BMCA-CLIP) using average accuracy. The best and second-best performances among the models are highlighted in bold and underlined, respectively.

caption: Table 6: \dataset dataset statistics: Counts of articles, image-caption pairs, metadata, human annotators and specialties.
description: This table presents a summary of the BIOMEDICA dataset's statistics.  It shows the counts of articles included, the number of image-caption pairs, the amount of metadata associated with each entry, and the number of human annotators and their specialities who contributed to the dataset's curation.

caption: Table 7: Overview of dataset statistics, detailing text token and character lengths, and image dimensions. For text statistics, tokens are generated using the BPE tokenizer from the tiktoken library
description: This table presents a statistical overview of the BIOMEDICA dataset, focusing on text and image characteristics.  It details the token and character counts for captions, figure references, and full text within the dataset. The token counts were generated using the Byte Pair Encoding (BPE) tokenizer from the tiktoken library.  Additionally, the table provides statistics on image dimensions (width and height in pixels).

caption: Table 8: Total Serialization time by PMC-OA subset
description: This table presents the time taken to serialize the PubMed Central Open Access (PMC-OA) dataset into the BIOMEDICA format, broken down by the license type of the articles.  It shows the total time to serialize the entire dataset, as well as the time spent on articles with commercial, non-commercial, and other licenses. This data highlights the efficiency of the dataset creation process.
